index.title: index
index.content:
This note is outcome of fall 24 Math 444. Elementary Real Analysis in UIUC, taught by professor Marius Junge.
The number after sub-heading indicates the number of class(e.g. Def 37.3 means 3rd point in class #37) and the book is Introduction to Real Analysis 4th Edition by Robert G. Bartle.

intergerbrableAndDiff/Darboux-integral.title: Darboux integral
intergerbrableAndDiff/Darboux-integral.content:
Def 27.3
for partition \delta \subset [a, b]

\Delta_j = x_{j - 1} - x_j
\inf_I f = \inf_{x \in I} f(x) and \sup_I f = \sup_{x \in I} f(x)
\underline{\sum}_\sigma = \sum^{n - 1}_{j = 0} \Delta_j \inf_{I_j}f and \overline{\sum}_\sigma = \sum^{n - 1}_{j = 0} \Delta_j \sup_{I_j}f where I_j = [x_j, x_{j + i}]

Thm 29.1
Then we can take I=\lim_k \overline{\sum}_{\tau_k} f  and \tau_k = \{x^k_j \mid 0 \leq j \leq 2^k\} where \tau_k \subset \tau_{k + 1}.
Indeed we can say \overline{\sum}_{\tau_{k + 1}} \leq \overline{\sum}_{\tau_k} and (\overline{\sum}_{\tau_k}) is bounded below and monotone decreasing, which imply it is convergent.
Remarks:

x^k_j means j-th element in x^k partition
x^k partition means we evenly split it into 2^k elements

Lemma 28.2
For two partition \sigma \subset \tau
\underline{\sum}_\sigma f \leq \underline{\sum}_\tau f \leq R_\tau(R, \xi) \leq \overline{\sum}_\tau \leq \overline{\sum}_\sigma f
where R is Riemann integral
Basically, if the largest sub-interval is larger, we will get more inaccurate result.
Lemma 28.3
For two partition \sigma \subset \tau , M = \sup(f(x) - f(y)) which is the worst difference where a \leq x, y \leq b, we can say \overline{\sum}_\tau \leq \overline{\sum}_\sigma f \leq \overline{\sum}_\tau + |\tau| M(\#\tau - \#\sigma) where \# is the number of that set.

intergerbrableAndDiff/Power-theory.title: Power theory
intergerbrableAndDiff/Power-theory.content:
Thm 37.1
For \sum a_kx^k = f(x) we can prove

f'(x) = \sum k a_k x^{k -1}
\int f(t) dt = \sum \frac{a_kx^{k+1}}{k+1}

Thm 37.2
For uniform limit \lim f_n' = g where g is continue and \lim f_n = f point-wise, we can say f'=g.
Thm 37.3
For \lim f_n = f is uniform limit and \lim f_n = f in Metric Space \Longrightarrow \lim \int f_n(t) dt = \int f(t) dt is uniform limit.
Def 37.4 Cauchy-Hadamard theorem
R = \left[ \lim_n \sup \sqrt[n]{|a_n|} \right]^{-1}
Props 37.5
(\forall r < R) f_n(x) = \sum^n_{k = 0} a_kx^k are uniformly Cauchy on C[-r,r]
Cor 37.6
(\forall r < R) f_n uniformly converge to f on [-r, r] and \sum a_kx^k convergent.
Lemma 37.7
\lim_n\sup \sqrt[n]{|a_n|} = \lim_n\sup\sqrt[n]{(k+1)|a_{n+1}|}=\lim_n\sup\sqrt[n]{\frac{|a_{n-1}|}{k}}
Thm 37.8
let (a_n) and R=\left( \lim_n\sup\sqrt[n]{|a_n|}\right)^{-1}
Then on (-R, R), f(x) = \sum_k a_kx^k is

Well defined
continue
differentiable
integrable

Def 38.1
\frac{1}{1-x} = \sum^\infty_{k=0} x^k
Remark 38.2

Radius of convergent comes from complex inequality.

Prop 38.3
\lim_k\sup \sqrt[k]{k} = 1

intergerbrableAndDiff/Riemann-integral.title: Riemann integral
intergerbrableAndDiff/Riemann-integral.content:
Def Def 28.1
R(f, \xi) = \sum_j^{||\xi||}\Delta_j f(\xi_j)
\sup R_\sigma(f, \xi) = \overline{\sum}_{\sigma} f
Where \overline{\sum} is in Darboux upper sum
Def 30.1
\lim_{n\longrightarrow\infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum^n_{j=1} f(a + j\frac{b-a}{n}) = \int^b_a f(x) dx
Lemma 30.2

R(f + \lambda g, \xi) = R(f, \xi) + \lambda R(g, \xi)
for [a, b] = [a, c] \cup [c, b]

\sigma = \sigma_{[a, c]} \cup \sigma_{[c, d]} where it’s partition
\Delta_{\sigma_{[a,c] \cup \{c\}}} + \Delta_{\sigma_{[c, b] \cup \{c\}}} \leq 2 \Delta_\sigma



Def 10.2
\Delta_\sigma(f) = \sum (x_{j + 1} - x_j)(\sup f - \inf f)

intergerbrableAndDiff/Trigonometry.title: Trigonometry
intergerbrableAndDiff/Trigonometry.content:
Basic recall

\sin'(x) = \cos(x)
\cos'(x) = -\sin(x)
\sin(0) = 0, \cos(0) = 1
\sin(\frac{\pi}{2})=1, \cos(\frac{\pi}{2}) = 0

Def 41.1
\pi = \sup\{x \mid \forall 0 < y < x, \cos(y) = \infty\}
Lemma 41.2
|\sin(x)| \leq |x|
proved by Thm 32.1 Fundamental Theorem and (\forall t)\cos(t)\leq 1 with
\sin(x) - \sin(0) = \int^x_0 \sin'(t)dt = \int^x_0 \cos(t)dt \leq x \leq |x|
\square
Remark 41.3
1-\cos(x) = \int^x_0 \sin(t)dt

intergerbrableAndDiff/differentiable.title: differentiable
intergerbrableAndDiff/differentiable.content:
Def 31.3
F is differentiable at x if
(\exists a)(\forall \varepsilon > 0)(\exists \delta)|x - y| < \delta \Longrightarrow |\frac{F(y) - F(x)}{y - x} - a| < \varepsilon
where we can say a =  F'(x)
Thm 31.4
differentiable f on (a, b) and f'(x) bounded \Longrightarrow f is Lipschitz
Thm 32.1 Fundamental Theorem

\int^x_ag'(t)dt = g(x) - c
if F' is integrable, F(b) - F(a) = \int^b_a F'(t)dt

Thm 32.2 Mean Value Theorem(MVT)
let f be continue on [a,b] and f is differentiable on (a, b)
(\exists \xi \in (a,b)) \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a} = f'(\xi)
Rolle’s Lemma
Let f be continue on [a, b] and differentiable on (a,b)
f(a) = f(b) \Longrightarrow (\exists \xi) f'(\xi) = 0
Rules

(f = \lambda g)' = f' + \lambda g'
(f\circ g)' = (f' \circ g)g'
(fg)' = f'g + fg'
f \in [a,b] is strict monotone, f^{-1} is continue

Thm 40.1 Chain rule
(f\circ g)' = f'(g(x))g'(x)
Prop 40.1
Let g: \mathbb{R} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}
\frac{d}{dy} \int^b_a g(y,t)dt = \int^b_a \frac{d}{dy}g(y, t)dt
Thm 40.2 differential
H'(a) = \lim_n \frac{H(a + \xi_n) - H(a)}{\xi_n}

intergerbrableAndDiff/integrable.title: integrable
intergerbrableAndDiff/integrable.content:
Def 28.5 pg. 228 Darboux integrable
For I = [a,b] and f:I \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} be a bounded function. Then f is Darboux integrable if (\exists \tau)(\forall \varepsilon > 0)\overline{\sum}_\tau f - \underline{\sum}_\tau f < \varepsilon
Def 28.1 Riemann integrable
(\exists I)(\forall \varepsilon > 0)(\exists \delta)(\exists \sigma)(\exists\xi) |\sigma| < \delta \Longrightarrow |R(f, \xi) - I| < \varepsilon
where \sigma is a partition, \delta is the max mesh size, and \xi is a set with points from every sub-interval in \sigma, R is Riemann Sum.
Thm 28.4
Darboux integrable imply Riemann integrable
Thm 29.5
f continue imply f integrable
Lemma 10.4
let \Phi be Lipschitz and f integrable, we have \Phi \circ f integrable.
Also \Delta_\sigma(\Phi \circ f) \leq L \Delta_\sigma(f)
Thm 31.1 Lebesgue’s Criterion for Riemann Integrability
f is bounded and \exists k \subseteq [a,b], the following are equivalent:

f is Riemann integrable on k
the set of discontinuities of f on k has Lebesgue measure zero
Basically, it means, f is only discontinue in measure zero set, and continue otherwise.

Thm 31.2
\varphi is continue, f integrable \Longrightarrow \varphi \circ f integrable
OH 35.1
Thm A
\varphi Lipschitz and f integrable \Longrightarrow \varphi \circ f integrable
Thm B
\varphi continue and f integrable \Longrightarrow \varphi \circ f integrable
Proof
By Thm C, we can say there exists S has Lebesgue Zero Measure.
Thm C
f integrable \iff (\exists S) has Lebesgue Zero Measure

intergerbrableAndDiff/integral.title: integral
intergerbrableAndDiff/integral.content:
Def 29.3
\int^b_a f(x) dx = I = \lim_k \overline{\sum}_{\tau_k} f= \lim R(f, \xi)
if f is integrable
Prop 29.4
\forall \sigma

\underline{\sum}_\sigma f \leq \int ^b_a f(x) dx \leq \overline{\sum}_\sigma f
| \int^b_a f(x) dx | \leq \overline{\sum}_\sigma |f|
|\int^b_a f(x) dx| \leq \int_a^b |f(x)| dx

Thm 30.3
for f, g is integrable

\int^b_a (f(t) + \lambda g(t))dt = \int^b_a f(t)dt + \lambda\int^b_a g(t)dt
\int^b_af(t)dt = \int^c_af(t)dt + \int^b_c f(t)dt

Thm 30.5
|\int^b_a f dt| \leq \int^b_a |f| dt
proved by considering \Phi(y) = |y| as a Lipschitz function.
Def 31.5
By Oresme
\int^1_0 x^mdx = \frac{1}{m+1}
Prop 41.3
\int^b_a f(s) ds \leq (b-a)\sup_s f(s)

intergerbrableAndDiff/mesh.title: mesh
intergerbrableAndDiff/mesh.content:
Def pg. 200
The mesh (or norm) of partition is defined by
|| \mathcal{P} || = \max\{x_1 - x_0, x_2 - x_1, \dots, x_n - x_{n - 1}\}
which is the largest length of all sub-interval

intergerbrableAndDiff/partition.title: partition
intergerbrableAndDiff/partition.content:
Def pg. 199
For a closed bounded interval [a, b], we can say \mathcal{P}=\{x_{i-1}, x_i\}^n_{i=1}  is it’s partition where x_0 = a and x_n = b. By definition, we can say \mathcal{P} is the set of points that split the [a, b] into many non-overlapped sub-interval.

intergerbrableAndDiff/proofs/Problem-of-.title: Problem of class 38
intergerbrableAndDiff/proofs/Problem-of-.content:
For $$
f(z) = \frac{1}{(z - i)(z + i)}

consider $f(z) = \frac{A}{z-i} + \frac{B}{z + i}$ and solve $A, B$
And it's $f(z) = \frac{-i/2}{z-i} + \frac{i/2}{z+i}$.
Then do power theory:
f(z) = \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{1}{1 - (\frac{-z}{i})} + \frac{1}{1-\frac{z}{i}}\right) = \frac{1}{2}\left[\sum^\infty_{k=0} (\frac{-z}{i})^k + \sum^\infty_{k=0} (\frac{z}{i})^k\right]=\sum^\infty_{k=0} \frac{z^{2k}}{i^{2k}}
$\square$

intergerbrableAndDiff/proofs/Proofs-of-p.title: Proofs of pi

sequences/Cauchy-sequence.title: Cauchy sequence
sequences/Cauchy-sequence.content:
Def 14.1
(x_{n}) is called Cauchy if
(\forall \varepsilon > 0)(\exists n_0) (\forall n, m > n_0) d(x_n, x_m) < \varepsilon 
Thm
All convergent sequence in complete Metric Space is Cauchy sequence.

sequences/Delta-ball.title: Delta-ball

sequences/Lipschitz.title: Lipschitz
sequences/Lipschitz.content:
Def 17.3
f:(x, d) \longrightarrow (y, d') is called Lipschitz
if d(f(x), f(y)) \leq k d(x, y)
where k>0 is called Lipschtz constant
Thm pg.143
if f: A \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} is Lipschitz function, f is uniformly continue in A
Thm 24.1
The best(smallest) Lipschitz constant equal to the first order derivative of a differentiable function.
OH 35.1
Thm D
for f continue, f' bounded and f' integrable \Longrightarrow f Lipschitz
Proof
by FT:
f(b) - f(a) = \int^b_a f'(t)dt \leq \overline\sum\Delta\sup f(\xi) \leq (b-a)\sup_kf(\xi_k)
Thm E
\exists f' and f' is bounded \Longrightarrow f is Lipschitz
Proof
by MVT
(\exists \xi \in (a,b)) \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a} = f'(\xi)
\Longrightarrow f(b) - f(a) = f'(\xi)(b-a) \leq (b-a) \sup f'
Thm
f uniformly continue \Longrightarrow f Lipschitz

sequences/Metric-Space.title: Metric Space
sequences/Metric-Space.content:
Def 13.1
(X, d) is called metric space
0) X is set

d: X \times X \longrightarrow [0, \alpha)

d(x, y) = d(y, x)
d(x, y) = 0 \iff x = y
d(x ,y) \leq d(x, z) + d(z, y)



3 standard choices of distance function 17.4

d_\infty(x, y) = \max_d |x(d) - y(d)|
d_2(x, y) = \sqrt{\sum_d |x(d) - y(d)|^2}
d_1(x, y) = \sum_{d=1}^d |x(d) - y(d)|

sequences/bounded.title: bounded
sequences/bounded.content:
Def for R
For sequence (x_n), we can say it’s bounded if
(\exists M > 0)(\forall n \in \mathbb{N}) |x_n| < M
Def 23.5
A set S \in X is called bounded if there
(\exists R > 0)(\exists x \in X) S \subset B_R(x)
Where B_R is a Delta-ball.
Def
If we say a function is bounded, we can say
(\exists M > 0)(\forall x)|f(x)| < M

sequences/closed.title: closed
sequences/closed.content:
Def
A set is closed if

It’s complement set is open
All cluster points are in the set

Prop 15.2
C \subset X
TFAE

C is closed
C is sequentially Closed

sequences/closure.title: closure
sequences/closure.content:
Def 17.1
\bar{S} = \{\lim_k x_k \mid x_k \in S \} \cup S
is closure of set S, it has following properties

\bar{S} is closed
\bar{S} is smallest closed set which contain set S

Def 18.1
S is dense in \bar{S}
(\forall y \in \bar{S})(\exists x \in S)(\forall \varepsilon > 0) d(x, y) < \varepsilon

sequences/cluster-points.title: cluster points
sequences/cluster-points.content:
Def pg.104
For set A \subset \mathbb{R}, if c \in \mathbb{R} is cluster point, we can say
(\forall \varepsilon > 0)(\exists x \neq c \in A) |x - c| < \varepsilon
Basically, for common Metric Space, it’s equivalent to the limit point.

sequences/compact.title: compact
sequences/compact.content:
Def pg.346 21.5
A Metric Space (S, d) is compact if each open cover of S has finite subcover.
Lemma 21.6
S is compact \Longrightarrow totally bounded
Thm 21.7
S \subset (X, d) TFAE

S compact
S is closed, totally bounded
S is sequentially compact

Thm 28 OH
For C \subset X compact and continue function f: X \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}

\sup_{x \in C} f(x) < \infty
(\exists x_0 \in X) \sup_{x \in C} f(x) = f(x_0) according to every continue function reach it’s maximum.

Heine–Borel theorem
S \subset \mathbb{R}^d

S is compact, where every open cover has finite subcover
S is closed and bounded

sequences/complete.title: complete
sequences/complete.content:
Def 14.2
A metric space is complete if every Cauchy sequence in X is convergent to some points in the set X.
Thm 15.1
For X(C, d) a Metric Space
TFAE

C is closed
(C, d) is complete

Thm 17.6 Existence of completion
For (X, d) is a Metric Space, then there exists a complete Metric Space \underline{Y} and \phi: X \longrightarrow \underline{Y}

d_\underline{Y}(\phi(x), \phi(y)) = d(x, y)
\phi(x) is dense in \underline{Y}

Def 18.3
completion is unique(too complex to prove)

sequences/connected.title: connected
sequences/connected.content:
Def 19.1
A set S is not connected if exists open set O_1, O_2 such that

S \subseteq O_1 \cup O_2
S \land O_1 \neq \emptyset
S\land O_2 \neq \emptyset
S \cap O_1 \cap O_2 = \emptyset

Thm 19.2
S \subset \mathbb{R} is connected \iff S is interval
Thm 19.3
for f: X \longrightarrow Y continue, S connected \Longrightarrow f(S) connected
Thm Intermediate value 19.4
f: [a, b] \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} be continue, y \in [f(a), f(b)] \Longrightarrow (\exists a \leq t \leq b)p(t) = y

sequences/continue.title: continue
sequences/continue.content:
Def 16.1
f is continue imply
 d(x, x') < \varepsilon \Longrightarrow d(f(x), f(x')) < \varepsilon
Thm 16.2
f is continue at x \iff (\lim_n x_n = x \Longrightarrow \lim_n f(x_n) = f(x))
Thm 16.3 17.2
f: x \longrightarrow y TFAE

f is continuous
it’s inverse image f^{-1}(O) is open for all open image O

Thm 17.5
A Metric Space (X, d) and f, g \in C(X, \mathbb{R})

f + g \in C(X, \mathbb{R})
f\times g \in C(X, \mathbb{R})
\exists \phi: \mathbb{R} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} \text{ c.t. } \Longrightarrow \phi \circ f \in C(X, \mathbb{R})
where C is the set of all continue functions from X to \mathbb{R}

Thm 17.7
The uniform limit of continuous functions is continue
Thm
continue \iff sequentially continue
Thm 35.2
inverse function of continue function is continue

sequences/convergent.title: convergent
sequences/convergent.content:
Def
\lim_n(x_n) = x' \iff (\forall \varepsilon > 0)(\exists n_0)(\forall n \geq n_0) |x_n - x'| < \varepsilon

sequences/interval.title: interval
sequences/interval.content:
five types:

Open
Closed
half-open/closed
infinity open
infinity closed

Def pg.47
If (\forall x,y \in S) x > y \Longrightarrow [x, y] \subseteq S is true, then S is interval.

sequences/neighborhood.title: neighborhood
sequences/neighborhood.content:
Def pg. 326
A neighborhood of a point x \in \mathbb{R} is any set V that contains an \varepsilon-neighborhood V_\varepsilon(x) := (x - \varepsilon, x + \varepsilon) of x for some \varepsilon > 0.

sequences/open-cover.title: open cover
sequences/open-cover.content:
Def pg. 333
let A \subset \mathbb{R}, an open cover of A is a collection \mathcal{G} = \{G_\alpha\} where all G_\alpha is open, such that
A \subseteq \bigcup_\alpha G_\alpha

sequences/open-set.title: open set
sequences/open-set.content:
Def 16.4
\emptyset is open
Def pg. 327

A subset G of \mathbb{R} is open set in \mathbb{R} if for each x \in G there exits a neighborhood V of x that V \subseteq G.
A subset F of \mathbb{R} is closed in \mathbb{R} if the complement C(F) := \mathbb{R} \backslash F is open in \mathbb{R}

sequences/path-connected.title: path connected
sequences/path-connected.content:
Def Path connected 19.5
S \subset X is path connected if x \neq y \in S (\exists \gamma: [0, 1] \longrightarrow S) \gamma continue and \gamma(0) = x and \gamma(1) = y
Thm 19.6
path connected \Longrightarrow connected
Example
we can prove it’s path connected by manually making a path. e.g.
f as upper bound and g as lower bound, we can make 3 paths and concat them.

go up to f from start x coordination
go through f to end x coordination
go down to end y coordination

sequences/proofs/3-lemmas-of-class-28.title: 3 lemmas of class 28
sequences/proofs/3-lemmas-of-class-28.content:
Lemma 23.3
For set S \subset X, S is totally bounded \Longrightarrow S is bounded.
Suppose S is totally bounded, we have
(\forall \varepsilon > 0)(\exists m)(\exists x_1, x_2, \dots, x_m \in X) \bigcup^m_{\alpha = 1} S \subset B_\varepsilon(x_\alpha)
and we want to prove that
(\exists R > 0)(\exists x \in X) S \subset B_R(x)
Then take \varepsilon = 1 and take x = x_\alpha where \alpha \leq m, we can take R = \max(\{d(x_\alpha, x_k) \mid x_k \in X \}) which is the max distance between every points in X.
After that, it’s safe to say S is bounded. \square
Lemma 23.4
For set S \subset \mathbb{R}^d, S is bounded \Longrightarrow S is totally bounded

sequences/proofs/Practice-of-exam-2.title: Practice of exam 2
sequences/proofs/Practice-of-exam-2.content:
2. Closure is closed
Let (x_n) \subset \mathbb{R}. Show that
S = \{x_n | n \in \mathbb{N}\} \cup Lim(x_n)
is closed. Show that S is compact \iff (x_n) is bounded.
Firstly, we can prove S is closed by contradiction: suppose there exists (x_{n_j}) \subseteq S such that \lim(x_{n_j}) \not\in S, we have two cases:

If (x_{n_j}) \subseteq (x_n),  it leads to a contradiction with lim(x_{n_j}) \not\in S due to Lim(x_n) \subset S and \lim(x_{n_j}) \in Lim(x_n).
If A = (x_{n_j}) \backslash (x_n) \neq \emptyset and \lim(x_{n_j}) = x', we can say A \subset Lim(x_n) and \lim(x_{n_j}) = \lim(A) \in Lim(x_n) which leads to a contradiction with \lim(x_{n_j}) \not\in S.
Hence in both cases we can say S is closed proved by contradiction. \square

sequences/proofs/Problem-of-OH-after-cla.title: Problem of OH after class 28
sequences/proofs/Problem-of-OH-after-cla.content:
For S \subset X compact and a x \not\in S
Show \exists \varepsilon > 0, s.t.
\inf_{y \in S} d(x, y) \geq \varepsilon > 0
Then according to d(x, y) is continue, we can say f(y) = -d(x, y) is also continue.
After that we can say
(\exists y_0) \sup_{y \in S} f(y) = f(y_0)
is true by Thm 28 OH. According to x \not\in S, we can say f(y_0) \neq 0 is true.
Hence we can take \varepsilon = d(x, y_0) and
\inf_{y \in S} d(x, y) \geq \varepsilon = d(x, y_0) > 0
is true. \square

sequences/proofs/proof-of-Thm-15.1.title: proof of Thm 15.1
sequences/proofs/proof-of-Thm-15.1.content:
Thm 15.1
For X(C, d) a Metric Space
proof 1 → 2
Suppose C is closed, we want to prove X is complete.
Consider (x_n) \subseteq C as an arbitrary Cauchy sequence in C, according to C is closed, which imply C is sequentially Closed by Prop 15.2, we can say
\lim_n (x_n) = x' \Longrightarrow x' \in (x_n)
is true. Hence it’s safe to say X is complete. \square
proof 2 → 1
Suppose X is complete, we want to prove C is closed.

sequences/proofs/proof-of-Thm-21.7.title: proof of Thm 21.7
sequences/proofs/proof-of-Thm-21.7.content:
Compact - Thm 21.7
Proof 1 → 2
For compact set K \subseteq \mathbb{R},
Bounded
we can prove it’s bounded at first by:
Consider H_m = (-m, m) as an open set, then according to
K \subseteq \bigcup_{m = 1}^\infty H_m = \mathbb{R}
we can say H_m is an subcover of K. According to K is compact, we can say (H_m) is finite. Then we have
K \subseteq \bigcup_{m = 1}^M H_m = (-M, M)
Hence, we can say K is bounded by (-M, M).
\square
Closed
Proof 3 → 2

sequences/sequentially-Closed.title: sequentially Closed
sequences/sequentially-Closed.content:
Def 8.5
[a, b] is sequentially closed imply
(\exists x = \lim_n (x_n))(a \leq x_n \leq b) \Longrightarrow a \leq x \leq b \Longrightarrow x \in [a, b]
Basically, all limits of it’s sub-sequences are in itself.

sequences/sequentially-compact.title: sequentially compact
sequences/sequentially-compact.content:
for common Metric Space, compact \iff sequentially compact

Def 20.1
S \subset (X, d) is called sequentially compact if every sequence has a convergence subsequence with limit in S
Lemma 20.2
for compact sequence S
T \subseteq S is closed \Longrightarrow T is sequentially compact
Thm 20.3 21.1
S \subseteq \mathbb{R}^d and sequence S compact or sequentially compact \iff

S is bounded
S is closed

sequences/sequentially-continue.title: sequentially continue
sequences/sequentially-continue.content:
Def 7.6
A function f: I \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} is called sequentially continue if
(\lim_n x_n = x) \Longrightarrow (\lim_n f(x_n) = f(x))
Thm 8.1
All sequentially continue function on [a, b] attain it’s maximum

sequences/subcover.title: subcover
sequences/subcover.content:
Def pg. 333

The construction of \mathcal{G} is in open cover

If \mathcal{G}' is a sub-collection of \mathcal{G} such that it’s union also contain origin set A, then \mathcal{G}' is called subcover of \mathcal{G}. If \mathcal{G}' has consist of finitely many set, we can call \mathcal{G}' a finite subcover of \mathcal{G}.
Def 21.4
A subcover of open cover is an open cover

sequences/totally-bounded.title: totally bounded
sequences/totally-bounded.content:
Def 21.1
S \subset X is totally bounded if
(\forall \varepsilon > 0)(\exists m)(\exists x_1, x_2, \dots, x_m \in X)
S \subset \bigcup_{\alpha = 1}^m B_\varepsilon(x_\alpha)
where B_\varepsilon is Delta-ball.
Thm 21.1
totally bounded \Longrightarrow bounded

sequences/uniform-limit.title: uniform limit
sequences/uniform-limit.content:
Def pg. 243
A sequence of function (f_n) on A \subseteq \mathbb{R} to \mathbb{R} converges uniformly on A_0 \subseteq A to a function f: A_0 \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} if for all x \in A_0
(\forall \varepsilon > 0)(\exists K(\varepsilon))(\forall n \geq K(\varepsilon)) |f_n(x) - f(x)| < \varepsilon
Claim 18.2
\lim_{n \longrightarrow \infty} d_\infty(f_n, f) = 0

sequences/uniformly-continue.title: uniformly continue
sequences/uniformly-continue.content:
Def pg. 143
let A \subseteq \mathbb{R} and let f: A \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}.  We say f is uniformly continue if
(\forall \varepsilon > 0)(\exists \delta(\varepsilon) > 0)(\forall x,u \in A) d(x , u) < \delta(\varepsilon) \Longrightarrow d(f(x), f(u)) < \varepsilon
Thm Uniformly continuity theorem pg. 143
Let I be a bounded closed interval and let f: I \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} be continue on I. Then f is uniformly continue on I.
Thm pg.144
If f: A \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} is uniformly continue on A \subseteq \mathbb{R} and if (x_n) is Cauchy sequence in A, then (f(x_n)) is Cauchy sequence in \mathbb{R}
Thm 27.1
For f: C \longrightarrow y is continue and C is compact, we can say f is uniformly continue.
Thm 27.2
For C compact, y complete, f: D \longrightarrow y and D \subset C is dense, TFAE:

F: C \longrightarrow y continue and F \mid_D = f(means f is F when domain is restricted to D)
f is uniformly continue
